bf013cbc-1690-404b-a460-91a02a910fb3.description: The Fundamentals of Online Advertising session will explore the evolution of the online advertising ecosystem and a variety of related topics, including basic ad delivery and reporting, online and mobile platforms and data flows, real-time bidding (RTB), and analytics, as well as an overview of the current developments affecting the future of ad tech.
bf013cbc-1690-404b-a460-91a02a910fb3.name: Fundamentals of Online Advertising

issuer.summary: issued by Future of Privacy Forum

badge_template_activities.title: Complete a 2-hour course on the basics of online advertising and its evolution.
Trainees will gain an understanding of how browsers work, the flow of data between websites, ad tech providers, and intermediaries; and the terminology.
Trainees will learn about the intricacies of programmatic advertising, including real-time bidding (RTB), and the interplay between the various participants in the ecosystem.

Trainees will understand the challenges affecting the future of online advertising, including deprecation of third-party cookies, platform requirements for tracking in mobile apps, and key laws and regulations that guide the ad tech sector.

60b11c35-863f-4bb6-84bb-79380f9356dc.description: Going beyond the fundamentals of online advertising, this session provides an in-depth examination of the online advertising ecosystem focusing on a variety of topics, including mobile platforms, consent frameworks, analytics, and the technologies behind them.
60b11c35-863f-4bb6-84bb-79380f9356dc.name: Beyond the Basics of Online Advertising

issuer.summary: issued by Future of Privacy Forum

badge_template_activities.title: This course will also explore the challenges affecting the future of online advertising, including deprecation of third-party cookies, platform requirements related to tracking, and key laws and regulations shaping the ad tech sector, as well as technologies developed to address user and legal requirements globally.

daa3d003-c181-4f75-8263-689c6f6144a4.description: Biometric technologies measure physical characteristics and apply statistical analysis to identify an individual, verify identity, or make related inferences. Biometrics are often used to unlock smartphones, access bank accounts, travel, and enter physical workspaces. Biometric systems can increase security and enhance products. At the same time, they rely on highly sensitive information, can create serious privacy risks, and raise important questions about compliance with legal, ethical, and
daa3d003-c181-4f75-8263-689c6f6144a4.name: Biometrics - Head to Toe

issuer.summary: issued by Future of Privacy Forum

badge_template_activities.title: Trainees will learn how biometrics systems work, including definitions, technology processes, and common systems such as facial recognition, fingerprints, voice, and behavioral characterization.
Trainees will learn the benefits and risks, including efficiencies, potential harms, and privacy considerations.

Trainees will learn about common commercial applications of the technology in healthcare, advertising, employment, and education contexts and social and ethical considerations, including law enforcement uses, regulatory frameworks, and standards setting initiatives.

bc996693-af7c-4ddd-a8b7-793eaba61e3b.description: Explore why de-identification can serve as an effective tool to preserve the privacy of individuals, in adherence to current standards and regulations for the protection of personal data. Using a risk-based approach, this training session covers re-identification methods for the secondary use of data that allows organizations to innovate without compromising privacy.
bc996693-af7c-4ddd-a8b7-793eaba61e3b.name: De-Identification

issuer.summary: issued by Future of Privacy Forum

badge_template_activities.title: Trainees will learn the basics of identifiability, including technical and legal definitions
Trainees will learn about structure data, including clinical trial datasets and real-world datasets

Trainees will learn multiple practical data transformation techniques, such as risk-based de-identification methods and synthetic data generation; data-privacy risk measurement and management exercise, using technical, legal, and organizational controls

606658d5-453d-4ab9-924b-da9b0db8685e.description: Privacy in the U.S. is a complicated maze of federal agencies, state and sectoral laws . Include international data flows, such as EU-US cross-border data transfer rules and Privacy Shield and it can be hard to keep track of all the nuances. This course will take a broad view of the existing U.S. privacy law through the lens of the FTC, proposed federal legislation, comprehensive state privacy laws and sectoral issues; followed followed by a discussion around international data flows.
606658d5-453d-4ab9-924b-da9b0db8685e.name: U.S. Privacy Landscape

issuer.summary: issued by Future of Privacy Forum

badge_template_activities.title: The landscape of existing U.S. Privacy Law including an introduction and deep dive into the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), including Section 5 and FTC Case Studies.
A look into Federal Legislation, The American Data Privacy and Protection Act (ADPPA) as well as Comprehensive State Privacy Laws.
Sectoral Issues and Legislation, including Children and Youth, Biometrics, Automated Decision-Making (AI) and Health Data.
International Data Flows, such as Privacy Shield, Schrems II, BCRs/SCCs and lastly adequacy requirements.
